channel.title: ðŸª´ Quartz 3 on
channel.description: Recent content in ðŸª´ Quartz 3 on

item.description: Registrar This step is only applicable if you are using a custom domain! If you are using a <YOUR-USERNAME>.github.io domain, you can skip this step.

item.title: (co)fiber sequences
item.description: Idea Taking the ordinary fiber twice is always trivial, meaning given a morphism $f:X\to Y$, we can take the fiber once to obtain $\text{fib}(f)\to X\to Y$.

item.title: (co)fibrant resolution
item.description: Idea As discussed in [model categories and derived functors](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/model categories and derived functors.md), we can have, say, functors which are homotopical (preserve weak equivalences) only on “good” (i.

item.title: (co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence
item.description: For example, we can regard $S^n$ as the colimit $$D^n\sqcup_{S^{n-1}}D^n\cong S^n.$$ Now $D^n\simeq \ast$, but $$\ast\sqcup \ast\not\simeq S^n.$$

item.title: (co)tangent space (of a variety)
item.description: Tangent space Recall the [differential of a regular map](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Regular map.md). Direct definition Given an [algebraic set](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md) $U={F_1=0,\dots,F_m=0}$, we may the define the tangent space of $U$ at the point $p$ as the solution set $$T_pU={\text{d}_pF_1=\dots=\text{d}_pF_m=0}.

item.title: 1- Introduction
item.description: Definition. Let $G$ be a group and $\mathbb{F}$ a field. Let $V$ be a vector space over $\mathbb{F}$. Then a homomorphism $$ T:G\longrightarrow GL(V) $$ is called a representation of $G$.

item.title: 1- Introduction to Finite Fields
item.description: Lecture notes Euler function Definition 1.1 ([Euler totient function](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Euler totient function.md)). Let $a$ and $n$ be positive integers. Then the Euler totient function $\phi(n)$ is defined as $$ \phi(n)\coloneqq # {a\leq n: \text{gcd}(a,n)=1}, $$ or the number of integers $\leq n$ that are relatively prime to $n$.

item.title: 2- More Finite Fields
item.description: Lecture Notes [Theorem 1.7.](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Field Theory/Finite Fields of Prime Power Order.md) Let $p$ be prime, and $f$ be a positive integer. Let $q=p^f$.

item.title: A Pedantic Approach to Galois Theory
item.description: Definition. Let $\text{ExtF}_k$ denote the category of field extensions over $k$. Its objects are field extensions over $k$, i.e. fields $K$ such that there is a natural inclusion $k\hookrightarrow K$.

item.title: absolute galois group
item.description: Idea The absolute Galois group of $F$ can be thought of as the Galois group of the maximal Galois extension of $F$, namely the [separable closure](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/separable closure.

item.title: Absolute value
item.description: Let $K$ be a field. Definition. A map $|\cdot|\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ is called an absolute value when $|x|=0 \iff x=0$ $|\cdot|$ restricted to $K^\ast$ is a homomorphism $K^\ast\to\mathbb{R}^\ast_{\geq 0}$.

item.title: Absolute value as action on R
item.description: Related [Absolute value](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.md)

item.title: adjoint representation
item.description: Definition There are two closely related notions that may be mixed up in terminology. By the representation $Ad$ we mean a representation from a lie group to its [lie algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/lie algebra.

item.title: adjoints preserve (co)limits
item.description: left adjoints preserve colimits and right adjoints preserve limits

item.title: Affine coordinate ring
item.description: Idea It is natural to want to study functions on mathematical objects of interest. In our case, functions are polynomials and the objects are algebraic sets.

item.title: Affine space
item.description: Let $K$ be an algebraically closed field. Let $A=K[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. Definition. The affine space of dimension $n$, denoted $\mathbb{A}_K^n$ (or just $\mathbb{A}^n$ if context is clear) is defined to be the set of $n$-tuples of $K$: $$ \mathbb{A}^n={(a_1,\dots,a_n)\mid a_i\in K} $$

item.title: Affine variety
item.description: Definition. A [algebraic subset](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md) $A\subset\mathbb{A}^n$ is called an affine variety if it is irreducible. Definition. The dimension of an affine variety $X$ is defined as $$ \dim(X)=\max{k\in\mathbb{N}\mid X\supsetneq X_1\supsetneq \cdots\supsetneq X_k} $$ where each $X_i$ is a nonempty affine variety.

item.title: AG dictionary
item.description: Geometry Algebra Affine algebraic set $X$ f.g. $K$-algebra without nilpotents $A=K[X]$. Embedding $X\subset\mathbb{A}^n$ Choice of generators of $A$ $f:X\to Y$ $f^\ast: K[Y]\to K[X]$ $X$ is irreducible (an affine variety) $A=K[X]$ is a domain $f$ is dominant ($\overline{f(X)}=Y$) $f^\ast$ is injective $f$ is a closed embedding $f^\ast$ is surjective (Closed embedding means $f$ is an isomorphism onto its image and $f(X)$ is closed in $Y$.

item.title: Algebra (over a field)
item.description: Definition. Let $K$ be a field and let $R$ be a vector space over $K$ equipped with a bilinear product:

item.title: Algebraic extensions
item.description: Idea An algebraic element is the zero of some polynomial. An algebraic extension is an extension in which every element is algebraic.

item.title: Algebraic subset
item.description: Affine Let $k$ be an algebraically closed field. Let $A=k[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. For $T\subset A$, and define $$Z(T)={P\in \mathbb{A}^n\mid f(P)=0 \text{ for all } f\in T}.

item.title: Algebraic subsets can be decomposed
item.description: Theorem. If $V\subseteq\mathbb{A}^n$ is an algebraic subset, then $V$ can be reduced into finitely many irreducible components: $$ V=V_1\cup \cdots\cup V_n.

item.title: Algebraically closed field
item.description: Pre-definition. A field $L$ is called algebraically closed if and only if any polynomial in one variable with coefficients in $L$ splits to a product of factors of degree 1.

item.title: Annihilator
item.description: Definition Let $R$ be a ring and $M$ an $R$-module. Definition. The annihilator of a subset $S\subset M$ is the set of elements in $R$ which yield 0 when multiplied by any element in $S$.

item.title: Any Field Hom is Injective
item.description: Theorem. Any field homomorphism is injective.

item.title: Artin-Wedderburn
item.description: Statement Let $A$ be a [central simple algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md) over $F$. Then $$A\cong M_n(D),$$ where $D$ is a division $F$-algebra that is unique up to isomorphism.

item.title: Artinian ring
item.description: Definition Rings Let $A$ be a commutative ring. Definition. $A$ is called Artinian if every ascending chain of ideals stabilizes, i.

item.title: associated p-adic algebra
item.description: Extending definitions ([trace](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/trace.md)) We may extend the bilinear form $Tr_{K/k}(ab)$ from $K$ to $V_\mathfrak{p}$ by $\widehat{k_\mathfrak{p}}$-linearity. Using the notation $\langle \ , \ \rangle$ for the resulting form, $$\langle a,b\rangle=\sum Tr_{K_i/\widehat{k_\mathfrak{p}}}(\pi_i(a)\pi_i(b))$$ ([Lattice](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Lattice.

item.title: Associated primes
item.description: Definition Let $R$ be a ring and let $M$ be an $R$-module. Definition. A prime $P$ of $R$ is associated to $M$ if $P$ is the [Annihilator](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Annihilator.

item.title: Automorphisms of a category
item.description: Consider two categories $C$ and $D$. Let $F:C\to D$ be a functor. Proposition. $F$ induces a group homomorphism between the automorphism groups of $C$ and $D$.

item.title: Axiom of Choice
item.description: [Zorn’s lemma](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Zorn’s lemma.md)

item.title: base change, ascent
item.description: Vector spaces Consider a field extension $L/K$. Given a $K$-vector space $W$, how may we extend this to an $L$-vector space?

item.title: Category of field extensions
item.description: The category of fields is poorly behaved. Maybe consider the category of field extensions, as it immediately is seen to have initial (and terminal?

item.title: Cayley-Hamilton theorem
item.description: General case Traditionally, endomorphisms (over a vector space, for example) were viewed as matrices. Thus the natural analogy is as follows: given an endomorphism, there exists a polynomial…

item.title: central simple algebra
item.description: Definition An $F$-algebra $A$ is called central if the center is equal to $F$, i.e. $$Z(A)={a\in A:ab=ba\ \forall b\in A} = F\cdot 1_A.

item.title: chain complex
item.description: Definition A sequence of modules such that $d^2=0$, i.e. the image of the previous map is contained in the kernel of the next map.

item.title: chain homotopy
item.description: Definition Let $f,g:C_\bullet\to D_\bullet$ be maps between [chain complex](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Homological algebra/chain complex.md)es. $f$ and $g$ are homotopic, denoted $f\simeq g$, if there exist maps $h_\bullet$ such that

item.title: Character of a representation
item.description: Idea Eigenvalues play a very important role in understanding invariant subspaces of a representation, and thus the representations themselves. Calculating eigenvalues for every element of $G$ can be very tedious, though.

item.title: Characteristic of a Field
item.description: Let $K$ be any field. Consider the ring homomorphism $$ \begin{gathered} \mathbb{Z}\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}{K} \ 1\mapsto 1_K \end{gathered}. $$ $\text{ker}(i)$ is an ideal of $\mathbb{Z}$, and must be principal since every ideal in $\mathbb{Z}$ is principal (has a generator).

item.title: Characters are an orthonormal basis for class functions
item.description: Related [Character of a representation](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Character of a representation.md) [Class function](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Class function.md)

item.title: Chinese Remainder Theorem
item.description: For ideals Theorem. If $I_1,\ddots,I_k$ are pairwise [coprime ideals](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Ideal.md), then $I_1\cap\cdots\cap I_k=I_1\cdot \dots \cdot I_k$ $\phi:A\to\prod_i A/I_i$ is surjective

item.title: Class 3
item.description: [Cayley-Hamilton theorem](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Cayley-Hamilton theorem.md) [Nakayama’s lemma](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nakayama’s lemma.md) [Local ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Local ring.md), [Localization of a ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Localization of a ring.md)

item.title: Class 4
item.description: [AG dictionary](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Algebraic geometry/AG dictionary.md) Projective sets, regular functions [Projective space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.md) [Regular map](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Regular map.md) Projective nullstellensatz [Nullstellensatz](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nullstellensatz.

item.title: Class 4
item.description: [Artinian ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Artinian ring.md) [Noetherian](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md) and Artinian modules [Tensor product (of modules)](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Tensor product (of modules).md)

item.title: Class 5
item.description: Projective, quasi-projective algebraic sets if Y is quasi projective, then for all y there is an open affine neighborhood containing y regular maps between quasi projective sets given such a regular map, there exists a covering of the domain such that the map can be written componentwise as homogeneous polynomials.

item.title: Class 5
item.description: associated primes and primary decomposition hensel

item.title: Class 6
item.description: Image of regular map from projective alg set to quasi proj is closed Rational functions X quasi proj, Y in X open nonempty then K(X) cong K(Y)

item.title: Class 7
item.description: $K\supset k=\bar{k}$. Then $K\cong k(X)$ for some $X\iff K$ is fg over $k$. trasendence, basis of transendence dimension

item.title: Class function
item.description: Definition A class function is one that is invariant under conjugation, i.e., given a group $G$ and a function $f$ with domain $G$, we say that $f$ is a class function if $f(h^{-1}gh)=f(g)$ for all any $g,h\in G$.

item.title: Closeness in p-adic numbers
item.description: Two [p-adic numbers](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/P-adic numbers.md) are close if they are both divisible by $p^n$ for $n$ large. From the page:

item.title: cohomology is dual to homotopy
item.description: Cohomology of $X$ concerns $\text{Hom}(X,A)$ for different choices of $A$. Homotopy of $X$ concerns $\text{Hom}(B,X)$ for different choices of $B$.

item.title: coordinate ring
item.description: Definition Let $V$ be an [Algebraic subset](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md) of $k^n$, $k$ algebraically closed. The coordinate ring of $V$, denoted $k[V]$, is the $k$-algebra of $k$-valued functions on $V$ obtained by restricting polynomial functions to $V$.

item.title: core
item.description: Idea The normal core of a subgroup $H\subset G$ is the largest normal subgroup of $G$ contained in $H$. Definition Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup.

item.title: Currying
item.description: Idea When defining functions of multiple variables, we could use the cartesian product. Alternatively, we can define them without product types by using currying.

item.title: dedekind domain
item.description: Idea Locally, at least away from prime ideals, a Dedekind domain looks like a [discrete valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.

item.title: Defining types
item.description: To define a type, the following must be specified: Formation: how to form new types of this kind, e.g. for a function type we need to have two types.

item.title: Dependent function types
item.description: Idea Given a type $A:\mathcal{U}$, there is a notion of a [family](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Logic/Type theory/Families of types.md) $B:A\to \mathcal{U}$ which sends elements in $A$ to types.

item.title: derived functors (homological algebra)
item.description: Idea Let us consider $A$-modules. Consider a functor $F$. Then given maps $M_1\to N$ and $M_1\hookrightarrow M_2$, if an extension $M_2\to N$ exists then the extension $F(M_2)\to F(N)$ also exists.

item.title: different
item.description: Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md), $k$ its field of fractions and $K/k$ a finite separable [extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Dimension of ring
item.description: Definition Definition. The dimension of a ring is the maximum length of an ascending chain of [prime ideals](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Prime ideal.md) $$ \mathfrak{p}_0\subsetneq\mathfrak{p}_1\subsetneq\cdots\subsetneq\mathfrak{p}_n\subsetneq A.

item.title: direct limit
item.description: Idea A direct limit is a special kind of colimit. It’s naming is a consequence of them being defined before categorical formalism, and also for the fact that one can guess what diagram the colimit is over, etc.

item.title: discrete G-set
item.description: Definition A topological group is say to act (continuously) on a topological space $X$ if the action map $$G\times X\to X$$ is continuous Here $G\times X$ has the product topology.

item.title: discrete valuation ring
item.description: Idea There is a direct analogy to complex analysis. Given a pole, we are often interested in its order. The structure of a DVR axiomatizes this notion of order.

item.title: discriminant
item.description: Dedekind domains Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md) and $k$ its field of fractions, $K$ a finite separable [extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Dual object
item.description: Let $C$ be a closed [monoidal category](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Monoidal category.md). Definition. The dual of an object $A$ is the internal hom $[A,I]$ where $I$ is the [unit object](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Unit object.

item.title: Dual spaces vs. inner product
item.description: Dual spaces are motivated by the lack of inner product. By constructing them we replace the Related [Dual vector space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Linear algebra/Dual vector space.

item.title: Dual vector space
item.description: Traditional definition Between vector spaces Let $V$ be a vector space over a field $F$. Definition. The dual space of $V$, denoted $V^\ast$, is the vector space $\text{Hom}(V,F)$.

item.title: Duality between affine and projective space
item.description: Related [Affine space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.md) [Projective space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.md)

item.title: Eisenstein polynomial
item.description: Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a complete [discrete valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.md) $\mathfrak{p}$ its maximal ideal A separable polyomial $$P(T)=T^n+\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}a_iT^i\in\mathcal{O}[T]$$ is called Eisenstein iff all $a_i\in\mathfrak{p}$ and $v_\mathfrak{p}(a_0)=1$.

item.title: etale algebras
item.description: Idea Dual to [etale space](notes/ntpy/etale space.md) of schemes. Stable under [base change, ascent](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/base change, ascent.md). Definition Let $F$ b a field.

item.title: etale space
item.description: Definition Let $B\in\text{Top}$, and $x\in B$. An etale space over $B$ is an object $E\in\text{Top}$ equipped with a map $$p:E\to B$$ such that $p$ is a local homeomorphism.

item.title: Euler totient function
item.description: Totient function Let $a$ and $n$ be positive integers. Then the Euler totient function $\phi(n)$ is defined as $$ \phi(n)\coloneqq # {a\leq n: \text{gcd}(a,n)=1}, $$ or the number of integers $\leq n$ that are relatively prime to $n$.

item.title: Every polynomial is a characteristic polynomial
exponential (lie theory)
item.description: Idea References https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1140556/reconstructing-lie-group-globally-from-the-exponential-map

item.title: ext functor
item.description: Idea $\text{Ext}^1(C,A)$ corresponds to extensions of $B$ modulo an equivalence relation. 0 corresponds to trivial extension. Properties $R^\bullet\text{Hom}(-,N)=R^\bullet\text{Hom}(M,-)$

item.title: ext functor as extension
item.description: Definitions Recall that an extension of $C$ by $A$ is an exact sequence of the form $$0\to A\to B\to C\to 0.

item.title: Extension and contraction of a ring
item.description: Definition Let $A$ and $B$ be commutative rings and $f:A\to B$ a ring homomorphism. Definition. Given an ideal $\mathfrak{a}\subset A$, its extension under $f$ is the ideal in $B$ generated by its image: $$\mathfrak{a}^e$ = (f(\mathfrak{a}))\subset B.

item.title: extensions of p-adic absolute values
item.description: Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md) $\mathfrak{p}\subset\mathcal{O}$ a nonzero prime ideal $k$ its field of fractions $\widehat{k_\mathfrak{p}}$ the completion of $k$ with respect to the [absolute value](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.

item.title: Extent to which ideals determine a ring
item.description: Do ideals determine a ring? A spectrum? Related [Ideal](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Ideal.md)

item.title: exterior algebra
item.description: Idea This construction forms the [exterior powers](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Linear algebra/exterior powers.md) into a graded algebra. Definition The exterior algebra is defined as $$\Lambda^\bullet V=\bigoplus_{k\geq 0}\Lambda^k V$$ We may define the multiplicative operation as follows: $$(e_{i_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{i_r})\wedge(e_{j_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{j_s})=e_{i_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{i_r}\wedge e_{j_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{j_s}.

item.title: exterior powers
item.description: Definition Let $V$ be a vector space of definition $n$ with basis $\langle e_1,\dots,e_n\rangle$. Then $k$th exterior power of $V$, for $k\geq 0$, is $$\begin{gather}\Lambda^kV=\langle e_{i_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{i_k}\rangle \ 1\leq i_1<\cdots<i_k\leq n\end{gather}$$

item.title: Families of types
item.description: Definition Definition. A family of type $A$ is a function $B:A\to\mathcal{U}$ whose codomain is a [universe](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Logic/Type theory/Universes.md). Example Family of finite sets $\text{Fin}:\mathbb{N}\to\mathcal{U}$ Constant type family $(\lambda(x:A).

item.title: Field Characteristic and Squares
item.description: Theorem. Let $p$ be prime and $f$ a positive integer. Let $K=\mathbb{F}_q$ be a field of characteristic $p$. Then If $p=2$, then every element in $K^\ast$ is a square.

item.title: Field extension
item.description: Definition Definition. Let $K$ and $L$ be fields. An subfield inclusion $K\hookrightarrow L$ is called a field extension. Any field homomorphism is automatically injective.

item.title: Field extensions behaving like fractions
item.description: Field extension dimensions behaving like fractions: L:K K:k =L:k Related [Field extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.md)

item.title: fields are not algebraic
item.description: Fields do not share nice properties with algebraic categories such as rings and groups because it isn’t one. In fact, rings and groups are monadic (a slightly stronger notion than algebraic, according to the definitions of some authors) but field are not.

item.title: finite dimensional lie algebras correspond to lie groups
item.description: This is not true generally.

item.title: Finite fields
item.description: Definition Properties $\mathbb{F}{p^m}\subset\mathbb{F}{p^n}$ iff $m\mid n$. Proofs 1 Every $\sigma\in\sum_{K/k}^{K/k}$ fixes $k$ by definition. Letting $k=\mathbb{F}_p$ and $K=\mathbb{F}_{p^n}$, this means $\sigma$ is a map such that $\alpha^p=\alpha$ for all $\alpha\in\mathbb{F}_p$.

item.title: Finite Fields of Prime Power Order
item.description: Let $p$ be prime, and $f$ be a positive integer. Let $q=p^f$. Let $\Omega$ be an algebraically closed field with characteristic $p$.

item.title: finite morphisms
item.description: Algebraic sets [Algebraic subset](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md) Let $X,Y$ be affine sets. Then a regular map $f:X\to Y$ is finite if $K[X]$ is finitely generated as a $f^\ast(K[Y])$-module.

item.title: Finite Mult. Subgroup of Field is Cyclic
item.description: Statement Let $K$ be a field and $K^\ast$ be its multiplicative group. Suppose $G\subset K^\ast$ is a finite subgroup. Then $G$ is cyclic.

item.title: five lemma
item.description: Statement In an abelian category, given a commutative diagram then if the rows are exact, $m$ and $p$ are isomorphisms, $l$ is epi, $q$ is mono, then $n$ is is an isomorphism.

item.title: flat module
item.description: Definition A module $M$ is flat over a ring $R$ if $M\otimes_R -$ is an exact functor. Properties Projective ([inj proj resolutions](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Homological algebra/inj proj resolutions.

item.title: Ford's Theorem
item.description: For every $k\geq 2$, there exists a totient number of multiplicity $n$ [Euler totient function](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Euler totient function.md). References https://en.

item.title: fractional ideal
item.description: Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be an [integral domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Integral domain.md), $k$ its field of fractions. An $\mathcal{O}$-submodule $I\subset k$ is called a fractional ideal iff $I\neq {0}$ and $I^{-1}\neq 0$.

item.title: Frobenius Map
item.description: Suppose $K$ is a field of characteristic $p$. The absolute Frobenius map is the map $$ \begin{gathered} \text{Fr}:K\to K \

item.title: Full, faithful functors
item.description: Definition Definition. A functor $F:C\to D$ is called full if for every pair of objects $c,c'\in C$ the induced map $$C[c,c']\to D[F(c),F(c')]$$ is surjective.

item.title: Functor representing unit object
item.description: If your going to take o functor represented by some object, consider the properties of the one represented by the unit object

item.title: Fundamental thm of Galois Theory
item.description: Finite case Suppose $K/k$ is a finite [Galois extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Galois extension.md). Let $G$ be its Galois group. Then

item.title: Galois connection as adjunction
item.description: The [Fundamental thm of Galois Theory](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Field Theory/Fundamental thm of Galois Theory.md) is a type of adjunction.

item.title: Galois descent
item.description: Idea The oppose of ascent, see [base change, ascent](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/base change, ascent.md). For vector spaces, it asks: given a field extension $L/K$ and a nonzero $L$-vector space $V$, how can we construct a $K$-vector space $W$ such that the $K$-basis of $W$ naturally extends to a $K$-basis (e.

item.title: Galois extension
item.description: Definition Definition. An [algebraic extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Algebraic extensions.md) $K/k$ is called Galois iff it is [separable](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Separable extension.

item.title: Galois group
item.description: Properties $G$ is profinite ([profinite group](notes/ntpy/profinite group.md)) $G$ is compact

item.title: galois theory and convering spaces
item.description: Idea Dictionary: connected coverings -> field extensions general coverings -> etale algebras choice of basepoint -> choice of separable closure Related [Fundamental thm of Galois Theory](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Field Theory/Fundamental thm of Galois Theory.

item.title: generalized cohomology
item.description: Idea We wish here to record the axioms of cohomology. In addition, we take the perspective that cohomology is a certain hom-functor (see [cohomology is dual to homotopy](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/cohomology is dual to homotopy.

item.title: Graded ring
item.description: Definition Definition. A graded ring is a ring $S$ together with a decomposition $$S=\bigoplus_{d\geq 0}S_d$$ of $S$ into a direct sum of abelian groups $S_d$ such that $$S_d\cdot S_e\subseteq S_{d+e}\quad\forall d,e\geq 0.

item.title: Grassmanian
item.description: Definition The Grassmanian $Gr(k,n)$ is, as a set, the collection of $k$-dimensional subspaces of the $n$-dimensional vector space $V$. $$Gr(k,n)=Gr(k,V)={W\subset V\mid \text{dim }W=k}$$

item.title: Grothendieck coverage
item.description: Idea An abstraction of the manner in which open sets cover a topological space. A category with a Grothendieck coverage is a site.

item.title: Group hom into abelian group
item.description: Homomorphism into a commutative group extends to homomorphism on domain modulo commutator

item.title: group objects
item.description: Idea A sense in which an object in some category behaves as though it has a group structure. The prototypical example is that of [topological group](notes/ntpy/topological group.

item.title: Hahn-Banach theorem
item.description: Statement 1 Let $X$ be an $\mathbb{R}$-linear space, $p$ a real-valued function on $X$ such that (positive homogeneity) $p(ax)=ap(x)$ for all $a>0$, $x\in X$.

item.title: Hensel's lemma
item.description: Suppose $f\in\mathbb{Z}_p[t]$. Let $f'$ be its derivative, and $n$ a positive integer. Theorem. Suppose $x\in\mathbb{Z}_p$ is such that $v_p(f'(x))=0$ and $f(x)\equiv 0\mod p^n$.

item.title: Hilbert basis theorem
item.description: Statement Theorem. If $R$ is a [Noetherian ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md), then $R[x]$ is a Noetherian ring. Proof. Let $I\subset R[x]$ be an ideal.

item.title: Ho(C) is badly behaved
item.description: The homotopy category of an $(\infty,1)$-category is not well behaved in the categorical sense. This is perhaps believable because the homotopy category truncates all higher morphisms.

item.title: Holomorphic function
item.description: Let $f$ be a complex valued function of a single variable. On an open set: Definition. A function $f(z)$ is holomorphic on an open set $U$ if it is (complex-)differentiable at every pointin $U$.

item.title: hom and tensor exactness
item.description: Let us consider $A$-modules. The $\text{Hom}(N,-)$ functor is left exact, and the functor $-\otimes_A N$ is right exact. [Exact functor](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Exact functor.

item.title: homotopy (co)fibers
item.description: Idea It is a rich complexity in homotopy theory that [(co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/(co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence.

item.title: Homotopy category
item.description: Relation to sSet In [nerve of category](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/nerve of category.md), we discuss that there is an adjunction witnessing the category of 1-categories (not higher!

item.title: homotopy category, nerve, and decategorification
item.description: Introduction We generally understand ordinary categories pretty well. By ordinary, we mean a (potentially small) category which is a collection of objects and morphisms adhering to a set of conditions.

item.title: Ideal
item.description: Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unit. Idea Given a subset $S\subset A$, the definition of an ideal is precisely the conditions necessary to make $A/S$ a ring:

item.title: Identity type
item.description: Definition We specify the following: Formation rule: given a type $A:\mathcal{U}$ and two elements $a,b: A$ we can form the type $(a=_A b):\mathcal{U}$.

item.title: index of lattice
item.description: Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md). Suppose $M$ and $N$ are two $\mathcal{O}$-[lattice](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Lattice.md). Then the index $$(M:N)_\mathcal{O}$$ is a [fractional ideal](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/fractional ideal.

item.title: infinite galois extensions
item.description: Properties $G$ is always uncountable. $G$ is compact Hausdorff (hence a [profinite group](notes/ntpy/profinite group.md) under the [Krull topology](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Krull topology.

item.title: inj proj modules
item.description: Definition All modules will be assumed to be $A$-modules where $A$ is a commutative ring with identity. Given any surjective map $$M\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow} N\to 0$$ we say that the module $P$ is projective if for any map $\phi$ there exists a map $\psi$ that extends it:

item.title: inj proj resolutions
item.description: Definition Given a module $M$, a projective resolution is an exact sequence $$ \dots\to P_{-1}\to P_0\to M\to 0$$ such that the $P_i$ are projective modules ([inj proj modules](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Homological algebra/inj proj modules.

item.title: Integral domain
item.description: Definition. An integral domain is a ring with no zero-divisors.

item.title: Integral element
item.description: Let $R$ be a commutative ring. Integral elements Definition. Let $A$ be a subring of $R$. An element $x\in R$ is said to be integral over $A$ if it is the root of a monic polynomial with coefficients in $A$.

item.title: integral extensions
item.description: Idea We wish to generalize the methods of field and Galois theory to (commutative) rings. A central notion in the aforementioned theory is that of [algebraic extensions](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Algebraic extensions.

item.title: inverse limit
item.description: Idea Inverse limits are dual to [direct limit](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/direct limit.md)s and are special kinds of categorical limits. Definition Let $(I,\leq)$ be a directed set (one can actually weaken this upper bound condition).

item.title: Is every gp representation completely reducible?
item.description: [Representation of a group](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.md)

item.title: Isometries of simplices
item.description: What do actions of isometry on geometric realizations of simplices do to their source in sSet?

item.title: jordan decomposition
item.description: Idea Qualitatively, the Jordan decomposition says that any endomorphism $X$ of a complex vector space may be expressed as the sum of a diagonalizable and a nilpotent endomorphism, and moreover these commute and may be expressed as polynomials in $X$: $$ X=X_s+X_n$$

item.title: Judgemental vs. propositional equality
item.description: Examples If we define $f(x)=x+x$, then $f(2)=2+2$ judgementally. If we are proving $a=b$, then $a=b$ propositionally.

item.title: Krasner's lemma
item.description: Statement Suppose $k$ is a field complete with respect to a non-archimedean absolute value $|\cdot|$. This can extended to the algebraic extensions.

item.title: Krull topology
item.description: Idea A special case of the [profinite topology](notes/ntpy/profinite topology.md). Definition Let $K/L$ be Galois, and $G=\text{Gal}(K/L)$. The Krull topology on $G$ is the one generated by the local [topological base](notes/ntpy/topological base.

item.title: Lambda abstraction
item.description: Idea We don’t always need to define a function by name. Definition Suppose we are defining functions from type $A$ to type $B$.

item.title: Lattice
item.description: Definition Suppose $\mathcal{O}$ is an integral domain, $k$ its field of fractions, and $K/k$ a finite separable [extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Legendre Symbol
item.description: Definition. Let $a$ be any residue modulo $p$. The Legendre symbol is $$ \left(\frac{a}{p}\right)\coloneqq a^{(p-1)/2} $$ Recall that if $a\neq 0$ then $\left(\frac{a}{p}\right)=\pm 1$.

item.title: lie algebra
item.description: Idea There are two principles that make the study of Lie algebras related to the structure of Lie groups: Let $G$ and $H$ be Lie groups, and $G$ is additionally connected.

item.title: lie algebras encode the group structure
item.description: Lie groups are groups with the structure of a smooth manifold. Intuitively, this means there is a way to “connect” all the local pictures into a global one, and this is precisely what the manifold does.

item.title: linear differential operators
item.description: Definition Let $A$ be a commutative $\mathbb{C}$-algebra with unit. Let $H(A)$ be the set of $\mathbb{C}$-linear endomorphisms of $A$. $H(A)$ is generally non-commutative.

item.title: Local ring
item.description: Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity. Definition. $R$ is called local if there exists just one [maximal ideal](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Maximal ideal.

item.title: Localization of a ring
item.description: Idea The localization of a ring $R$ at $U\subset R$ is a setting in which the elements of $U$ behave like [units](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Unit (ring).

item.title: lr adjoints imply lr exactness
item.description: If the functor $F$ is left adjoint to $G$, then $F$ is right exact and $G$ is left exact. This is a corollary of the stronger result that left adjoints preserve colimits and right adjoints preserve limits ([here](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Category theory/adjoints preserve (co)limits.

item.title: map of modules induces chain map
item.description: Let $f:M\to N$ be a map of $A$-modules. Given a resolution for $N$ (i.e. an exact sequence $Q_\ast\to N\to 0$) and a projective complex over $M$ (see [chain complex](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Homological algebra/chain complex.

item.title: Maschke's Theorem
item.description: Theorem. (Maschke) Assume that a group $G$ is finite, $\mathbb{F}$ is a field, and $V$ is a vector space over $\mathbb{F}$.

item.title: Maximal ideal
item.description: Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unit. Definition. A proper ideal $M\subset A$ is called maximial if any of the following equivalent conditions hold:

item.title: Minimal polynomial
item.description: Definition Suppose $P\in k[T]$ is irreducible of degree $\geq 1$. Then $(P)$ is a maximal ideal in $k[T]$. $k_P\coloneqq k[T]/(P)$ is a field $[k_P:k]=\deg P$.

item.title: model categories and derived functors
item.description: Idea Consider two model categories, so that there are notions of fibrant and cofibrant objects. It is sometimes the case that such a functor almost behaves homotopically, by which we mean (almost) preserves weak equivalences.

item.title: model category
item.description: Idea To study the homotopy of a category, we wish to pass to a setting which isolates the phenomenon. This is because working with the entire category has “too much” information since we only want to consider things up to homotopy.

item.title: Module
item.description: Definition $M$ is called simple if it does not contain any nontrivial submodule. Dual Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.

item.title: Nakayama's lemma
item.description: Corollary. (Nakayama’s lemma). Let $I$ be an ideal contained in the [Jacobson radical](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Radical.md) of a ring $R$, and let $M$ be a finitely generated $R$-[module](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Module.

item.title: nerve of category
item.description: Idea Relation to homotopy Let $\partial\Delta[n]$ be the boundary or sphere of a simplex. In the nerve, in the case of $\partial\Delta[2]\to C$, this means a triangle It is apparent that there is a 2-cell $fg\Rightarrow h$ iff $h=fg$.

item.title: Nilpotent
item.description: Let $A$ be a ring. Definition. An element $a\in A$ in nilpotent if there exists $N\in\mathbb{N}$ such that $a^N=0$. Definition. The elements of a ring form an ideal $Nil(A)$ called the nilradical.

item.title: Noetherian concepts in stable homotopy theory
item.description: Related [Noetherian ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md)

item.title: Noetherian ring
item.description: Definition Rings Definition. A Noetherian ring is associative, commutative ring with identity $A$ such that one of the following equivalent conditions hold:

item.title: Normal extensions
item.description: Idea A normal extension $L/K$ is one that does not live “between” irreducible polynomialsâ€” it either contains all of the roots or none of them, similar to the idea of the [Prime Avoidance Lemma](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Prime Avoidance Lemma.

item.title: Nullstellensatz
item.description: Idea For a polynomial $f\in\mathbb{C}[x]$, we can split $f$ into linear factors. If you think about what this really means, it is saying that any finite collection of points, counting multiplicities, uniquely determines a polynomial up to scalar multiplication (e.

item.title: obstruction to division algebras being fields
item.description: Idea [central simple algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md)

item.title: Ostrowski's theorem
item.description: For a prime $p$, let $v_p(x)$ be the largest $n$ such that $p^n$ that divides $x$. Theorem. Let $|\cdot|$ be a nontrivial [absolute value](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.

item.title: over category
item.description: Definition Let $C$ be a category, and $c\in \text{Obj}(C)$. The over category of $C$ with respect to $c$, denoted $C/c$, has objects are arrows in $C$ with target $c$ arrows are arrows in $C$ making the obvious diagram commute.

item.title: P-adic numbers
item.description: Define $v_p(x)$ to be the largest power of $p$ that divides $x$. Define $v_p(0)=\infty$. Clearly $$ v_p(xy)=v_p(x)+v_p(y),\quad v_p(x+y)\geq\min{v_p(x),v_p(y)} $$ Definition Analytic definition Definition.

item.title: Perfect fields
item.description: A field of characteristic $p$ is perfect if $K^p=K$. Remark. All finite fields are perfect by the [Frobenius Map](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Frobenius Map.

item.title: Plucker quadric
item.description: Idea (include from [Grassmanian](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Grassmanian.md)) A net in $Q$ is a linear embedding $\mathbb{P}^2\subset\mathbb{P}^5$ such that $$\mathbb{P}^2\subset Q\subset\mathbb{P}^5.$$ Let $\pi$ be a net.

item.title: Polynomial ring
item.description: Properties Prime ideals If $R$ is a [Principal ideal domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Principal ideal domain.md), then the prime ideals of $R[y]$ are of the following form:

item.title: Primary decomposition
item.description: Idea

item.title: Prime Avoidance Lemma
item.description: Theorem. Suppose $p_1,\dots,p_n$ are prime ideals. Take an ideal $I$ such that $I\subset \bigcup_i p_i$. Then $I$ is contained entirely in some prime ideal: $I\subset p_i$ for some $i$.

item.title: Prime ideal
item.description: Definition Let $A$ be a (commutative) ring. Definition. An ideal $p\subset A$ is called prime if the following equivalent conditions are met:

item.title: primitive element
item.description: Dedekind domains Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md), $k$ its field of fractions, $K$ a finite separable [extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Principal ideal domain
item.description: Call the ring we are working in $A$. Definition. A principal ideal domain is an [integral domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Integral domain.md) in which every ideal is principal, meaning it is generated by a single element.

item.title: Product type
item.description: Idea In set theory, given two small sets $A$ and $B$ we define their Cartesian product $A\times B$ to be the set of elements of the form $(a,b)$ where $a\in A$ and $b\in B$.

item.title: profinite completion
item.description: Idea This construction takes any group and gives us an associated [profinite group](notes/ntpy/profinite group.md). The part “completion” in the name perhaps refers to the fact that a group is dense in its profinite completion.

item.title: profinite group
item.description: Definition A group $G$ is profinite if it is isomorphic to an [inverse limit](notes/ntpy/inverse limit.md) of finite groups. Remark.

item.title: profinite topology
item.description: Definition Let $G$ be a group. The profinite topology on $G$ is the one with base $$\mathcal{B}={\text{cosets of finite index normal subgroups}}$$ A [topological group](notes/ntpy/topological group.

item.title: Projective space
item.description: Algebraic sets Recall that a polynomial $F\in k[x_0,\dots,x_n]$ is called homogeneous of degree $d$ if $F(\lambda x_0,\dots,\lambda x_n)=\lambda^d\cdot F(x_0,\dots,x_n)$. If $T$ is a set of homogeneous elements of $S$, define the zero set of $T$: $$Z(T)={P\in\mathbb{P}^n\mid f(P)=0\text{ for all }f\in T}.

item.title: Projective variety
item.description: Definition Let $k$ be an algeraically closed field. Projective space The projective $n$-space, denoted $\mathbb{P}^n$, is the [affine space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.

item.title: pullback and pushforward of ES
item.description: Pullback Given a short exact sequence $$0\to A\to B\to C\to 0$$ and a map $g:C_1\to C$, we may construct the pullback along this map such that the following diagram commutes: Regarding the SES as an extension $E$, we write $E\circ g$ for the pullback.

item.title: Quadratic reciprocity
item.description: Theorem (Quadratic Reciprocity). Let $p$ and $l$ be two distinct primes. Then $$ \left(\frac{p}{l}\right)\left(\frac{l}{p}\right) = (-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\frac{l-1}{2}}. $$

item.title: quadric
item.description: Properties Let $Q$ be a quadric, $Q\subset\mathbb{P}^N$, $p\in Q$ a smooth point, $H\not\ni p$ a hyperplane. Then the projection from $p$ onto $H$ induces an isomorphism $$Q\setminus (Q\cap T_p Q)\cong H\setminus H(H\cap T_p Q).

item.title: quasi-proj varieties locally look like affine varieties
item.description: [Projective variety](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective variety.md) [Affine variety](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine variety.md)

item.title: quaternion algebra
item.description: Definition Properties Let $F$ be a field. ( Wedderburn) Assume the characteristic is not 2. Then any division $F$-algebra with $F$-dimension 4 is a quaternion algebra.

item.title: Quotient of Ring is Integral Domain iff Prime Ideal
item.description: Let $R$ be a commutative ring. The quotient $R/I$ is an integral domain if and only if $I$ is a prime ideal.

item.title: Radical
item.description: Let $A$ be a commutative ring. Definition Radical Definition. The radical of an ideal $I\subset A$, denoted $Rad(I)$, is the set $$ Rad(I)={ a\in A \mid a^N\in I \text{ for some } n\in\mathbb{N} }.

item.title: ramified extensions
item.description: Definition Suppose $\mathcal{O}$ is a complete [discrete valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.md) $\mathfrak{p}$ its maximal idea $k$ its field of fractions, $K/k$ a finite separable extension of degree $n$ $\mathcal{O}_K$ its [valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Valuation ring.

item.title: Reducibility of finite dimensional representations
item.description: Every finite dimensional representation is reducible. It is an [open question](notes/ntpy/Questions/Is every gp representation completely reducible?.md) whether this is true for infinite dimensional representations.

item.title: reflective subcategory
item.description: Idea Let $C$ be a category and $U$ a class of morphisms. An object $c\in C$ is called $U$-local if its representable functor $C(-,c)$ is an isomorphism for all $f\in U$.

item.title: Regular map
item.description: Definition Let $K$ be an algebraically closed field. In affine space Algebraic set > field Definition. Let $V$ be an [algebraic subset](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.

item.title: repreresentations of sl2C
item.description: Idea A general approach to determining the representations of a group, particularly a (semisimple) Lie algebra, is Decompose the vector space into a direct sum of eigenspaces Determine how the images of the group in $GL(V)$ act on these eigenspaces The reason this method is effective is because eigenspaces are a clear way to see invariant subspaces.

item.title: Representation of a group
item.description: Definition Traditional definition Definition. Let $G$ be a group and $\mathbb{F}$ a field. Let $V$ be a vector space over $\mathbb{F}$.

item.title: Representations are determined by their character
item.description: Related [Representation of a group](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.md) [Character of a representation](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Character of a representation.md)

item.title: Representations of homotopy category
item.description: Representations of homotopy category maybe tynctor is to homotopy group and consider representations of it undetermined to determine the group

item.title: representations of s3
item.description: Idea The general idea is the following: Consider the abelian subgroup $A_3\subset S_3$ generated by some 3-cycle $\tau$. The irreducible representations of a finite abelian group are 1-dimensional, hence we can decompose the representation $W$ of $A_3$ into a direct sum of spaces spanned by each of the three eigenvectors.

item.title: residue class degree, ramification index
item.description: Definition Suppose $\mathcal{O}_1\subset\mathcal{O}_2$ are [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)s, $\mathfrak{p}_1\subset\mathcal{O}_1$ and $\mathfrak{p}_2\subset\mathcal{O}_2$ are nonzero prime ideal such that $\mathfrak{p}_2$ [lies over](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Prime ideal.

item.title: Riemann Surface
item.description: Abstract Riemann Surface In the abstract sense, a Riemann surface is a real, 2-dimensional manifold with a useful notion of analytic functions.

item.title: ring of convergent power series
item.description: Definition Let $\mathbb{C}[[x]]$ denote the ring of formal power series in $\mathbb{C}$. $\mathbb{C}{x}\subset\mathbb{C}[]$ is the subring consisting of those power series $$\sum a_n x^n$$ which converge in some neighbhorhood of zero.

item.title: ring of differential operators on convergent power series
item.description: Definition Let $\mathcal{O}n$ be the [ring of convergent power series](notes/ntpy/ring of convergent power series.md) in $n$ variables, i.e. every element of $\mathcal{O}n$ has a series expansion $$f=\sum c\alpha x^\alpha,\quad\exists\delta>0\mid\sum|c\alpha|\cdot\delta^{|\alpha|}<\infty.

item.title: ring of integers
item.description: Operations ( norm) Suppose $I$ is an $\mathcal{O}K$-[fractional ideal](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/fractional ideal.md) in $K$. Then its norm is $$N{K/k}(I)\coloneqq(\mathcal{O}K:I)\mathcal{O}$$ Properties $N_{K/k}:\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{O}_K)\to\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{O})$ is a group homomorphism.

item.title: ringed space
item.description: Definition A ringed space $(X,\mathcal{O}_X)$ is a topological space $X$ together with a sheaf $\mathcal{O}_X$ of (perhaps commutative) rings. $\mathcal{O}_X$ is called the structure sheaf of $X$.

item.title: RS are domain of MV-functions
item.description: Paths connecting multiple values correspond to nontrivial cycles on the abstract RS.

item.title: RS berkeley article
item.description: Lecture 1 To deal with MV (complex) functions, make its domain the graph itself (think of $z^2=w$). Think function then is from the graph to the $w$ plane, i.

item.title: scheme
item.description: Idea According to [Nullstellensatz](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nullstellensatz.md), there is a one-to-one correspondence… … generalize varieties so that on the left we may take arbitrary commutative rings.

item.title: Schur's Lemma
item.description: Theorem. (Schur’s Lemma) Assume $T:G\to GL(V)$ is an irreducible complex resentation and $A\in \text{End}(T)$. Then $A=\lambda\text{Id}$ for some $\lambda\in \mathbb{C}$.

item.title: Semisimplicity
item.description: The a class of objects possesses the characterisitic of semisimplicity if every object can be decomposed into “simple” pieces. Examples Factorial rings [Unique factorization domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Unique factorization domain.

item.title: separable closure
item.description: Idea The separable closure of $F$, denoted $F^\text{sep}$, is the “biggest Galois extension of $F$”. This is the result of two facts:

item.title: Separable extension
item.description: Idea The idea of roots being “separable” in the sense that there are no repeated roots is important because it tells us we are working with a “simple” polynomial that can generate all other polynomials with this set of roots (see [Nullstellensatz](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nullstellensatz.

item.title: sheaf
item.description: Idea Definition Definition 1 (topological) Let us operate in a topological space $X$. Let $U$ be an open set with an open covering $\mathcal{U}$.

item.title: sheafification
item.description: Examples Locally constant sheaf One can show that $\mathbb{C}_X$ is a sheaf on $X$ whose stalks are all equal to $\mathbb{C}$.

item.title: sieve
item.description: Definition Let $C$ be a category, $c\in\text{Obj}(C)$. Let $C/c$ be the [over category](notes/ntpy/over category.md). A sieve $S$ is a collection of arrows in $C$ with target $c$ (i.

item.title: simple is weaker than transitive
item.description: Idea Related [central simple algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md)

item.title: Simple objects
item.description: Definition Let us work in a category with a [zero object](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Zero object.md). Definition. A simple object $A$ is one whose only [quotient objects](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Subobjects, quotient objects.

item.title: simplicial skeleton
item.description: Relation to homotopy For each $n\in\mathbb{N}$, the unit of the adjunction $$X\to\textbf{cosk}_n(X)$$ induces an isomorphism on all simplicial homotopy groups in degree $<n$.

item.title: site
item.description: Idea Consider

item.title: snake lemma
item.description: Statement In an abelian category, consider a commutative diagram where the rows are exact sequences and 0 is the [Zero object](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Zero object.

item.title: Solutions to polynomials determine a topology
item.description: The [algebraic subsets](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md) define a topology on [affine space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.md), namely the [Zariski topology](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Zariski topology.md).

item.title: split sequence
item.description: Definition A sequence $$0\to L\overset{i}{\longrightarrow} M\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow}N\to 0$$ is said to split if one of the following holds: There exists $s:N\to M$ such that $s\circ\pi=1_N$.

item.title: Splitting field
item.description: Idea Given a polynomial $f\in k[T]$, the splitting field $K$ of $f$ is the extension $K/k$ such that $f$ splits into linear factors into $K$ and is minimal in the sense that $K=k(\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_n)$ is generated by all roots of $f$.

item.title: Stability of semisimple categories?
item.description: If a category is not semi simple, are its higher categories semisimple? I.e, does the property of semisimiplicity stabilize? Linear representations The category of (finite) linear representations of a finite group (see details in [Representation of a group](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.

item.title: Stabilization
item.description: The phenomena where an infinite process terminates. Examples Nilpotent elements in a ring stabilize under the operation of taking powers [Nilpotent](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Nilpotent.

item.title: Subobjects, quotient objects
item.description: Definition Let $A$ be the object of some category. Definition. A subobject of $A$ is an equivalence class of [monomorphisms](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Mono, epimorphisms.

item.title: Subring of Field is Integral Domain
item.description: Every subring of a field (containing 1) is an integral domain.

item.title: Tate field
item.description: Definition The function $v_p$ extends in a unique way from $\mathbb{Q}_p^\ast$ to $\overline{\mathbb{Q}p^\ast}$ with the formula $$v_p(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{\text{deg }x}v_p(N{\mathbb{Q}_p(x)/\mathbb{Q}_p}(x))$$ with values in $\mathbb{Q}$ and defined (after choice of $1<s\in\mathbb{R})$ a nonarchimedean [absolute value](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.

item.title: tensor product (commutative algebra)
item.description: Of algebras Let $A,B$ be $R$-algebras, and $I,J$ ideals in $A,B$ respectively. Then $$(A/I)\otimes_R (B/J)\cong (A\otimes_R B)/(I\otimes_R 1+1\otimes_R J).$$ Let $M$ be an $A$-module.

item.title: Tensor product (of modules)
item.description: Definition Let $A$ be a commutative ring, and let $M$, $N$, and $K$ be $A$-modules. Definition. Then tensor product $M\otimes_A N$ is an $A$-module satisfying the following universal property: $$ \begin{array} zM\times N & \rightarrow & M\otimes_A N \

item.title: Tensor product of vector spaces
item.description: Finite dimensional case Let $V,U$ be finite dimensonal vector spaces over $K$. Let $Free(V,U)$ be the set of finite linear combinations $$\sum_{i=1}^na_i(x_i,y_i)$$ where $n\in\mathbb{Z}+$, $x_i\in V$, $y_i\in U$, and $a_i\in K$.

item.title: To What Extent does the Euler function determine n?
item.description: Totient numbers For a definition, see [Euler totient function](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Euler totient function.md). A theorem of Ford states that for every $k\geq 2$ there exists a totient number of multiplicity $k$.

item.title: topological base
item.description: Idea Topological bases allow us, in some cases, to more easily describe a topology. It “generates” the topology, in a sense.

item.title: topological group
item.description: Idea A group with a topology that interacts nicely with the group operations. Definition A topological group is a group with a topology such that the operations of “multiplication” $$ \begin{gather} G\times G\to G \ (g,h)\mapsto gh \end{gather} $$ and “inversion” $$ \begin{gather} G\to G \

item.title: trace
item.description: The trace determines an isomorphism from a space to its dual: $$\begin{gather} T:L\to L^\ast \ x\mapsto Tr(x\cdot (-)) \end{gather}$$ References https://math.

item.title: Tychanoff's theorem
item.description: Statement The infinite product of compact spaces is compact. The truth of this fact is equivalent to the truth of the [Axiom of Choice](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Axiom of Choice.

item.title: Unique factorization domain
item.description: Definition. A ring $R$ is said to be factorial if it can be represented uniquely (up to the multiplication by invertible elements) as a product of irreducible elements (an element is reducible if it can be written as the product of two noninvertible elements).

item.title: Unit (ring)
item.description: Let $A$ be a commutative ring with identity. Definition. A unit is an element $x\in A$ such that $xy=1$ for some $y\in A$.

item.title: Unit object
item.description: In a [monoidal category](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Monoidal category.md), a unit object is the unit of the tensor product, i.e. $a\otimes u\simeq a$ and $u\otimes a\simeq a$ for any $a$ in the category.

item.title: Unitary operator
item.description: Definition Let $V$ be an inner product space. Definition. An operator $A\in\text{End}(V)$ is called unitary if $$\langle Ax,Ay\rangle=\langle x,y\rangle,\quad\forall x,y\in V.

item.title: Universes
item.description: Definition Definition. A universe is a type whose elements are types. Definition. The types in a particular universe are called small types.

item.title: Valuation ring
item.description: Let $K$ be a field and $|\cdot|:K\to\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ a nonarchimedean [absolute value](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.md). Definition. The valuation ring of $K$ consists of all elements with absolute value $\leq 1$: $$ O={x\in K:|x|\leq 1} $$

item.title: Wedderburn
item.description: Statement Let $F$ be a field. Assume the characteristic is not 2. Then any division $F$-algebra with $F$-dimension 4 is a quaternion algebra.

item.title: Weyl algebra
item.description: Definition Let $K$ be a field of characteristic 0. $K=K[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. $\hat{x_i}\in \text{End}_K(K)$ be defined as $\hat{x_i}(f)=x_if$. (We really mean pointwise(?

item.title: When Product of Cyclic Groups is Cyclic
item.description: The product group $$ \mathbb{Z}{n_1}\times…\times\mathbb{Z}{n_m} $$ is cyclic if and only if the $n_1,\dots,n_m$ are pairwise relatively prime. In that case, it is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_{n_1\dots n_m}$.

item.title: Zariski topology
item.description: Definition On affine space Closed sets are the [algebraic subsets](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md). On projective space When defined on [Projective space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.

item.title: Zariski's lemma
item.description: Theorem. Let $K\subset L$ be a [field extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.md). Suppose $L$ is a finitely generated $K$ [algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Algebra (over a field).

item.title: Zorn's lemma
item.description: There are several formulations: Suppose a partially ordered set $P$ has the property that every chain in $P$ has an upper bound in $P$.
